posts.name: Tharun
posts.cooked: Hey I was recently setting up my PID COntroller Object and I had a few questions based on that. For example we are using the get Distance method from our encoder and we want it to read -750 so I set the kP to the value we had previously tuned and I had set kI to 0 however after doing so the voltage went to -25 and 25 and so I was wondering what I was doing wrong.

I’m confused; you want the getDistance() to read -750 of whatever unit? I don’t see the connection between that, your kP and kI values, and the voltage going from -25 to 25. Those are all (somewhat) independent numbers. Is the issue that the voltage went from negative to positive?

posts.name: Tharun
posts.cooked: Sorry for the confusion but getDistance() should end up being -750 and so I had a recursive PID that went to -750 where the kP value was set at 0.032. When I try this same kP value without increasing anything else I get an extremely large voltage that the sparkMax can’t take.

I’m assuming your current position is 0. Since your setpoint is -750, your error is -750. The proportional term of PID is simply e * kP , and -750 * 0.032 = -24, which explains the 24V output. You’re probably going to need to lower your kP.

posts.name: Tharun
posts.cooked: Ah ok I think the issue I was having was that im trying to write a PID for a chain and so a lot of the times the constants change a lot when the chain skips so I assume I had that for a previous constant and since the chain skipped it would have to be reset thank you so much!

posts.name: Ned FInkle
posts.cooked: Lower P and clamp your output with MathUtils.clamp(minOutput, maxOutput)

posts.name: Tharun
posts.cooked: Sorry im a little confused on what you mean by clamp the output? Do you mean just have it so that theres a deadband for the voltage and if it ever exceeds it the voltage being sent to the bot should end?
Clamping just limits the input to be within your desired min and max. Here’s the WPILib API documentation for it. The actual code is super simple:
